    Notice of address discrepancy means a notice sent to a user by a consumer reporting agency pursuant to 15 U.S.C. § 1681(c)(h)(1), that informs the user of a substantial difference between the address for the consumer that the user provided to request the consumer report and the address(es) in the agency's file for the consumer. 
(Ord. No. 39-09, § III, 7-16-09) 
Sec. 11-223. - Policy. 
    In the event that the city receives a notice of address discrepancy, the city employee responsible for verifying consumer addresses for the purpose of providing the municipal service or account sought by the consumer shall perform one (1) or more of the following activities, as determined to be appropriate by such employee: 
(1)  Compare the information in the consumer report with: 
a.  Information the city obtains and uses to verify a consumer's identity in accordance with the requirements of the customer information program rules implementing 31 U.S.C. § 5318(l); 
b.  Information the city maintains in its own records, such as applications for service, change of address notices, other customer account records or tax records; or 
c.  Information the city obtains from third-party sources that are deemed reliable by the relevant city employee; or 
(2)  Verify the information in the consumer report with the consumer. 
(Ord. No. 39-09, § III, 7-16-09) 
Sec. 11-224. - Furnishing consumer's address to consumer reporting agency. 
(a)  In the event that the city reasonably confirms that an address provided by a consumer to the city is accurate, the city is required to provide such address to the consumer reporting agency from which the city received a notice of address discrepancy with respect to such consumer. This information is required to be provided to the consumer reporting agency when: 
(1)  The city is able to form a reasonable belief that the consumer report relates to the consumer about whom the city requested the report; 
(2)  The city establishes a continuing relation with the consumer; and 
(3)  The city regularly and in the ordinary course of business provides information to the consumer reporting agency from which it received the notice of address discrepancy. 
(b)  Such information shall be provided to the consumer reporting agency as part of the information regularly provided by the city to such agency for the reporting period in which the city establishes a relationship with the customer. 
(Ord. No. 39-09, § III, 7-16-09) 
Sec. 11-225. - Methods of confirming consumer addresses. 
    The city employee charged with confirming consumer addresses may, in his or her discretion, confirm the accuracy of an address through one (1) or more of the following methods: 
(1)  Verifying the address with the consumer; 
(2)  Reviewing the city's records to verify the consumer's address; 
(3)  Verifying the address through third party sources; or 
(4)  Using other reasonable processes. 
(Ord. No. 39-09, § III, 7-16-09) 
Secs. 11-226-11-230. - Reserved. 
Chapter 12 - MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Uniform Rules of the Road adopted. 
(a)  Pursuant to chapter 6 of title 40 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, Code sections 40-6-372 through 40-6-377, title 40, chapter 6 [O.C.G.A. section 40-6-1 et seq.] (all known as the Uniform Rules of the Road) and the definitions contained in Code section 40-1-1 are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of this city with like effect as if recited herein. 
(b)  Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-6. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6001; Ord. No. 35-87, 11-5-87) 
Sec. 12-2. - Roller skates or blades, skate board, coasters, etc. 
(a)  No person upon roller skates or blades, skate boards, or riding in or by means of any coasters, toy vehicle, or similar device shall cross any roadway except while crossing a street on a crosswalk. When so crossing, any person shall be granted all the rights and shall be subject to all the duties applicable to pedestrians. 
(b)  There shall be no such skating or riding on the sidewalks and/or streets except under terms and conditions expressly allowed by the council by resolution or ordinance. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for persons skating or riding on sidewalks or streets to gather in crowds, to create noise, to be guilty of any disorderly conduct, to take hold of or hang on to any automobile or other vehicle, or to interfere in any way with the natural progress of automobiles or other vehicles along and in the streets of the city. It shall be unlawful for two (2) or more persons to join hands while skating on sidewalks or streets. Persons skating or riding on sidewalks shall give right-of-way to, and in no way interfere with, persons walking on the sidewalks. 
(d)  Persons shall only be allowed to skate on streets and/or sidewalks from thirty (30) minutes after sunrise to thirty (30) minutes before sunset. 
(e)  Persons shall be allowed to skate on any and all public streets in the city limits except for the following streets as indicated below. The city may supplement, change or make deletions to this list as it determines necessary for the general public health, safety and welfare.

(f)  In addition, no skating as authorized by this section will be allowed to be conducted on the property of the city of Cartersville. Except as designated in the city's recreation areas by the city's recreation director. 
(g)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall be subject to the penalties provided for violation of this chapter; provided, however that any such offender under the age of seventeen (17) years shall be dealt with as provided by law. The parent of any child and the guardian of the person of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6002; Ord. No. 01-95, 2-2-95) 
Sec. 12-3. - Slowly moving and heavily laden vehicles. 
(a)  Slowly moving or heavily laden vehicles shall not be driven upon the streets or highways abreast, but one must follow behind the other and keep as near the right-hand curb as possible. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to push or drive any vehicle propelled by human or animal power upon streets or areas specifically designated by the council. This prohibition shall apply to all bicycles, tricycles, pushcarts, animal-drawn vehicles of all kinds and all vehicles incapable of making a speed of at least twenty-five (25) miles per hour. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6017) 
Sec. 12-4. - Speed limits generally. 
    The speed limits on city streets shall be as specified in section 12-1002. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6007) 
State Law reference- Authority to establish speed limits, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-371(a)(10), 40-6-183. 
Sec. 12-5. - Speed limit for vehicles approaching or driving past men working. 
    The maximum rate of speed for any vehicle shall be fifteen (15) miles per hour when approaching or driving past men working in the street or roadway who are city employees, public utility employees, or those granted permission of the city, provided such workmen have erected a sign reading "Slow-Men Working" and such sign is in accordance with city specifications. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6018) 
Sec. 12-6. - Funeral processions. 
(a)  Vehicles of a funeral procession shall have the right-of-way over all vehicles, except authorized emergency vehicles, provided each shall identify itself by burning regular headlights and keeping in close formation. 
(b)  When the lead vehicle in a funeral procession has entered an intersection on a green light, all other cars in the procession may proceed through the intersection, even though such signal may change to red. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6013) 
Sec. 12-7. - Driving through funeral or other procession. 
    No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion and when such vehicles are conspicuously designated as required in section 12-6. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6014) 
Sec. 12-8. - Drivers in a procession. 
    Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the right-hand edge of the street or roadway as practicable and shall follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practicable and safe. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6015) 
Sec. 12-9. - Operation of trucks and motor vehicles over three tons. 
(a)  Fite Street from Cherokee Street (SR 293) to Etowah Drive is hereby closed to any through traffic by trucks and other motor vehicles over three (3) tons. 
(b)  Trucks or other motor vehicles over three (3) tons delivering to or picking up from a location on Fite Street from Cherokee Street (SR 293) to Etowah Drive are still allowed to make deliveries. 
(c)  A fine for violation of this section is not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) per violation. 
(Ord. No. 47-94, 11-23-94) 
Sec. 12-10. - Violation of OCGA, § 40-6-14. 
(a)  In addition to all fines imposed pursuant to state law and city ordinances for violations of OCGA, § 40-6-14 the judge of the municipal court is authorized to impose the additional fine and penalty. 
(1)  Any person found guilty of violating OCGA, § 40-6-14 shall be required to attend a one-hour class to listen to classical music selections as determined by the court and at a place designated by the court. 
(Ord. No. 49-99, 11-4-99) 
Secs. 12-11-12-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT

DIVISION 2. - TRAFFIC-CONTROL SIGNS, SIGNALS, DEVICES AND MARKINGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Traffic signs, signals and markings, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20 et seq. 

Sec. 12-36. - Existing signs, etc. 
    The erection or installation and location of all traffic-control signs, signals, devices and markings in place on the adoption date of this Code are ratified and confirmed. 
Sec. 12-37. - Public works director to place and maintain. 
    The public works director as directed by the council shall cause to be placed and maintained traffic-control signs, signals and devices when and as required under this chapter and other traffic ordinances of the city to make effective the provisions of this chapter and such ordinances. He may cause to be placed and maintained such additional traffic-control devices as he shall deem necessary to regulate traffic under this chapter, other traffic ordinances of this city, and state law, or to guide or warn traffic. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6031; Ord. No. 62-07, 11-15-07) 
Sec. 12-38. - Specifications; official status. 
    All traffic-control signs, signals and devices shall conform generally to specifications set out in the manual on Uniform Traffic-Control Devices adopted by the state highway board; however, all signs and signals placed pursuant to this article or other ordinance shall be official and shall so far as practicable be uniform as to type and location throughout the city. All traffic-control devices so erected shall be official traffic-control devices. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6033) 
Sec. 12-39. - Through streets. 
    The public works director shall erect and maintain stop signs or yield signs at the intersections of streets that are not designated as through streets with through streets. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6061; Ord. No. 62-07, 11-15-07) 
Sec. 12-40. - Locations of stop signs. 
    The locations of stop signs shall be as specified in section 12-1003. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6012(b)) 
State Law reference- Authority to erect stop signs, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(6). 
Sec. 12-41. - One-way roadways and highways. 
(a)  Whenever this chapter or any ordinance of the city designates any one-way roadway or highway the public works director shall place and maintain signs giving notice thereof. Signs indicating the direction of lawful traffic movement shall be placed at every intersection where movement of traffic in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(b)  One-way roadways and highways shall be as specified in section 12-1001. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6006; Ord. No. 62-07, 11-15-07) 
State Law reference- Authority to designate one-way streets, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-371(a)(4), 40-6-47. 
Sec. 12-42. - Speed limits, etc. 
    The public works director shall erect or cause to be erected at the direction of the council traffic-control devices and signs at appropriate locations throughout the city indicating the maximum speed limits and other information to inform drivers of traffic-control regulations applicable at such locations. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6016; Ord. No. 62-07, 11-15-07) 
Sec. 12-43. - Turn restrictions. 
(a)  The public works director when directed by the council is hereby authorized to determine those intersections at which drivers of vehicles shall not make right turns, left turns, or U-turns, and shall place proper signs at such intersections. The making of such turns may be prohibited between certain hours of any day and permitted at other hours, in which event the hours shall be plainly indicated on the signs or the signs may be removed when such turns are permitted. 
(b)  The public works director shall place turn restriction signs at the places and showing the restrictions specified in section 12-1004, which restrictions shall then be effective at such places. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6020; Ord. No. 5-87, § 2, 1-29-87; Ord. No. 62-07, 11-15-07) 
Sec. 12-44. - Obedience to signs prohibiting turns. 
    Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right turn, left turn, or U-turn is permitted, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of such signs. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6022) 
Sec. 12-45. - Turning markers. 
    The public works director is authorized to place markers, buttons and signs within or adjacent to intersections indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning at such intersections, and such course to be traveled as so indicated may conform to or be other than as prescribed by this chapter or other law or ordinance. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6021(a); Ord. No. 62-07, 11-15-07) 
State Law reference- Authority to restrict turns, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(9); turning movements, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-120 et seq. 
Sec. 12-46. - Designation of crosswalks, safety zones, and traffic lanes. 
(a)  The city is hereby authorized: 
(1)  To designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where in its opinion there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway and at such other places as may be deemed necessary. 
(2)  To establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as may be deemed necessary for the protection of pedestrians. 
(3)  To make lanes for traffic on street pavements at such places as may be deemed advisable, consistent with this chapter and other traffic ordinances of this city. 
(b)  Crosswalks, safety zones and traffic lanes shall be established and appropriately marked at any places designated in sections 12-1010, 12-1011, in addition to those otherwise authorized by this section. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6032; Ord. No. 5-87, § 3, 1-29-87) 
Secs. 12-47-12-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Abandoned vehicles, § 14-21 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate stopping, standing and parking, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(1); stopping, standing and parking generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-200. 

Sec. 12-61. - Obstruction of traffic. 
    No person shall park any vehicle upon a street in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten (10) feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic. Where an arterial or major and minor collector streets as indicated by the City of Cartersville Street Classification Map adopted on May 17, 2007 as amended, has a centerline, no person shall park a vehicle within twelve (12) feet of such centerline. No person shall park a vehicle in such a manner as to obstruct or interfere with the access of emergency vehicles through said street. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6041; Ord. No. 31-07, § 1, 7-5-07) 
Sec. 12-62. - Prohibitions; exception. 
(a)  No person shall park a vehicle upon any roadway for: 
(1)  Displaying it for sale. 
(2)  Greasing or repairing it except for repairs necessitated by sudden emergency; in such emergency such vehicles shall be moved or towed away with all due haste. 
(3)  Displaying advertising. 
(b)  The parking of vehicles shall be prohibited in the designated parking areas on the streets specified in section 12-1005, except that such prohibitions shall not apply during church hours on Sunday on portions of the streets adjacent to churches where parking will not unduly interfere with the safe flow of traffic thereon, the determination thereof to be by the chief of police, who shall cause such areas to be marked by signs permitting parking during such hours. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6042) 
Sec. 12-63. - Curb loading zones. 
    The chief of police at the direction of the council is hereby authorized to determine the location of passenger and freight curb loading zones and shall place and maintain appropriate signs indicating the zones and stating the hours during which the regulations applicable to such zones are effective. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6043) 
Sec. 12-64. - Stopping, etc., in curb loading zone. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger curb loading zone or freight in any place marked as a freight curb loading zone during the hours when the regulations applicable to such curb loading zone are effective. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6044) 
Sec. 12-65. - Liquid gas trucks. 
(a)  The overnight parking in residential areas of trucks loaded with liquid petroleum gas, liquid propane or liquid butane is hereby determined to be dangerous to the health, welfare, and safety of the citizens of the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to park a motor vehicle loaded with as much as one hundred (100) gallons of liquid petroleum gas, liquid propane or liquid butane to remain parked for more than three (3) consecutive hours in any place in the city other than the dealer's principal place of doing business. Should it be necessary to park any such vehicle at any other location for a period of time longer than permitted, the contents of the truck shall be drained. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6045) 
Sec. 12-66. - Parking time limited. 
(a)  The parking of vehicles shall be limited to two (2) hours in the designated parking areas on the streets specified in section 12-1006. 
(b)  The parking of vehicles shall be limited to one (1) hour in the designated parking areas on the streets specified in section 12-1007. 
(c)  The parking of vehicles shall be limited to a specified period shorter than one (1) hour when the parking area along with a time period is specified in section 12-1008 or 12-1009. 
(d)  The restrictions of subsections (a) and (b) shall be enforced from 9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday. 
(e)  The provisions of subsections (a) through (d) shall not affect no-parking areas and other restrictions on parking within the areas designated. 
(Code 1976, §§ 7-6046-7-6049; Ord. No. 43-86, 1-2-87) 
Sec. 12-67. - Large vehicles. 
    All trucks, trailers, campers and any other motor vehicle more than seven (7) feet wide or thirty (30) feet long shall be prohibited from parking on any street in the city with a surface less than thirty (30) feet wide. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6051; Ord. No. 12-77, 4-28-77) 
Sec. 12-68. - Tractor trailers and trucks-Parking with engine running in residential areas. 
    It shall be unlawful to park with the engine running in a truck or tractor trailer for more than thirty (30) minutes in any place on any residentially zoned property in the City of Cartersville, Georgia, or adjacent streets, roads or alleys thereto. 
(Ord. No. 10-94, § 3, 3-31-94) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-94, § 3, adopted March 31, 1994, has been codified herein at the discretion of the editor as § 12-68. 
Secs. 12-69-12-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SPEED TABLE ORDINANCE 

Sec. 12-101. - Purpose. 
    The objective of the City of Cartersville Speed Table Ordinance is to provide a process whereby residential street(s) may obtain speed tables on residential streets with a maximum posted speed limit of thirty (30) mph. Alternative traffic calming devices are available and may be considered separately or as part of this process. To qualify for the installation of speed tables, areas of affected streets must meet all requirements set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 22-14, § 1, 7-1-14) 
Sec. 12-102. - Definitions. 
(a)  85th percentile speed: An index of traffic speeds for a road segment used by transportation professionals for traffic analysis purposes. The 85th percentile speed is the speed at which eighty-five (85) percent of the motorists are driving at or below. 
(b)  Affected street(s): The actual street(s) proposed for speed table installation. Affected street property owners are the owners of the lots with any frontage, including side frontage, on the street(s) proposed for speed table installation. 
(c)  ADT: Stands for average daily traffic and is a unit of measure used by transportation professionals for traffic volume analysis. Average daily traffic for the purpose of this policy refers to the traffic in both directions on a particular street within a twenty-four-hour time period. 
(d)  City council: The mayor and city council. 
(e)  Contact person(s): The person(s) requesting in writing a study to determine if their particular residential streets(s) qualifies for the installation of speed tables. 
(f)  Resident: The owner of property on a residential subdivisions streets(s), or if the property owner of a rental property is not able to be contacted, the tenant of the rental property. 
(g)  Residential street: A section of city street(s) being considered for speed table installation that is bordered along the entirety of both sides by properties used for residential purposes with the exception of properties adjacent to significant cross streets or having no constructed vehicular access to the studied street. 
(h)  Speed table: A vertical type traffic-calming device designed to reduce motorist's speeds to the posted speed limit. 
(i)  Traffic calming: A term used by transportation professionals to refer to reducing traffic speeds. 
(Ord. No. 22-14, § 1, 7-1-14) 
Sec. 12-103. - Requirements for study. 
(a)  The following criteria must be met before a particular residential street(s) is studied for possible speed table installation: 
(1)  Local, residential street. The City of Cartersville must confirm that the requested streets are classified as local, residential streets with a maximum posted speed limit of thirty (30) mph, or below. In addition, the requested street(s) must be suitable for speed table installation: streets must be a minimum of one thousand (1,000) feet in length, and at least one thousand (1,000) feet of each street must have grades ten (10) percent or less and horizontal curves less severe than a radius of three hundred (300) feet. 
(2)  A request (in writing). The City of Cartersville must receive a written request from a resident (or residents) of a particular residential street(s) asking that their street(s) be studied to determine if any qualify for the installation of speed tables. The address of the resident making such request will be verified using the same procedures used for rezoning requests. 
(b)  Residential streets meeting the above criteria are added to the City of Cartersville list as a speed table study area for study purposes. 
(Ord. No. 22-14, § 1, 7-1-14) 
Sec. 12-104. - Validate speed and volume requirements. 
    Upon authorization by city council, a speed table request will be evaluated based upon the following study criteria. The following requirements have been established in determining if streets qualify for study regarding the possible installation of speed tables: 
Traffic data will be collected from selected residential street to determine the 85th percentile speed and the ADT. If the 85th percentile speed is ten (10) mph or more over the posted speed limit, and the ADT is between three hundred (300) and three thousand (3,000) vehicles, the residential street qualifies for a public meeting. 
(Ord. No. 22-14, § 1, 7-1-14) 
Sec. 12-105. - Public meeting. 
(a)  For all study areas that meet the previous requirements, a public meeting shall be held at which a representative of the public works department shall be present and take minutes for presentation to city council. Public meetings are held in order to provide speed table study area residents with relevant information prior to city council public hearings/readings. 
(b)  Prior to public meetings, public works shall mark the proposed speed table location(s) on the residential street(s) within three (3) feet of the final location(s) and shall subsequently verify that the resident(s) of property fronting the speed table location(s) agree with the proposed location(s). In the event that no suitable speed table location(s) can be agreed upon by public works and the resident(s) fronting the location(s), the matter will be brought forward to council for consideration prior to further action. 
(c)  Notices of the public meetings will be posted a minimum of fourteen (14) days prior to each meeting. Signs advertising the public meeting(s) will be provided and installed by the City of Cartersville Public Works Department. Signs will be clearly legible to traffic traveling in each direction near each end of the road section being considered for speed tables. Public meetings consist of a short presentation, followed by a question and comment session. The purpose of the public meeting is to provide reasonable accommodation for input from residents and others that may use the residential street(s) to access their lots. 
(d)  Emergency service providers (police, fire and ambulance) will be requested to provide information to the council related to the effects of installing speed tables in the requested study area. 
(Ord. No. 22-14, § 1, 7-1-14) 
Sec. 12-106. - Public hearing before city council. 
(a)  A public hearing shall be held to determine whether speed tables shall be installed on a residential street. Notice of public hearings shall follow the procedures in use at the time for providing notice for rezoning matters. Public hearings before the council will be conducted only for those locations that qualify for consideration under this policy. After the conclusion of the public hearing, the city council may then vote to approve/disapprove installation of speed tables in the study. Said approval shall be handled as an ordinance amendment. 
(b)  Emergency service providers (police, fire and ambulance) will be requested to provide information to the council related to the effects of installing speed tables in the requested study area. 
(Ord. No. 22-14, § 1, 7-1-14) 
Sec. 12-107. - Speed table design standards. 
    The geometric design of speed tables is a crucial factor in their effectiveness. City of Cartersville speed tables will be constructed per the following specifications: 
(1)  Vertical height. Three (3) inches. A tolerance for minor height differences due to construction variations may be permitted. 
(2)  Horizontal length. Twenty-two (22) feet (consisting of an incline of six (6) feet; a plateau of ten (10) feet in length; and a decline of six (6) feet). 
(3)  Spacing/placement. In order to be effective, speed tables are typically installed in a series. Spacing between tables will vary between a minimum spacing of three hundred (300) feet and a maximum spacing of eight hundred (800) feet or as recommended by public works. Minor changes in the proposed speed table location up to three (3) feet may be considering prior to installation of the speed tables based upon resident concerns and the engineering feasibility to make such modifications. 
(4)  Signs/pavement markings. Speed tables will be identified in accordance with signing and pavement marking standards in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, latest edition. In cases where special safety circumstances exist, public works may authorize signing and pavement marking exceeding the minimum standards set forth in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. 
(Ord. No. 22-14, § 1, 7-1-14) 
Sec. 12-108. - Installation of speed tables. 
    The property owners requesting the permanent traffic control devices will be responsible for the costs of the measures. Installation of speed tables will be performed by either a private contractor, contracted by the City of Cartersville, or by city forces. Installation of speed tables will not be considered final until the City of Cartersville Public Works Department inspects the tables for compliance with design standards set forth in this article. Under certain circumstances or extreme hardships, the cost may be funded by the city if funds are available. 
(Ord. No. 22-14, § 1, 7-1-14) 
Sec. 12-109. - Repeated requests. 
    In the case where a request fails because of failing to meet the required criteria or lack of affirmative vote by city, that street(s) must wait a minimum of two (2) years from the start date of the original request in order to make a subsequent request, unless special circumstances have had a noticeable effect on the study criteria outlined in this policy. Repeat requests must be in writing and meet the same requirements detailed in this article for original requests. The process will be identical to a new request and will begin with the initial phases outlined in this article. 
(Ord. No. 22-14, § 1, 7-1-14) 
Sec. 12-110. - Removal process. 
(a)  Written request(s) for removal of a speed table can only be made after the speed table has been installed for a minimum of four (4) years. In the event that a resident(s) of a particular residential street asks that speed tables be removed from the street, such request must be made in writing to the City of Cartersville Public Works Department. It shall be verified that the request is from a resident(s) who lives on the residential street(s), as verified by the same process used for rezoning requests. Once the requestor has been verified as a resident of the affected street(s), a notice of public hearing shall be posted. Notice of public hearing may follow the procedures in use at the time for providing notice for rezoning matters. After the conclusion of the public hearing, the city council may then vote to approve/disapprove removal of speed tables in the study using the procedure provided for to approve amendments to ordinances. 
(b)  Speed tables will not be removed unless approved by the city council. City of Cartersville reserves the right to remove speed tables for any reason. 
(Ord. No. 22-14, § 1, 7-1-14) 
Sec. 12-111. - Variance procedure. 
(a)  The city council, at its sole discretion, may vary from the procedure or standards set forth herein for any reason. 
(b)  Additionally, a resident of an affected street may request, in writing, that the city council grant a variance from the procedures or standards set forth in sections 12-101-12-107 of this article. Once a written variance request is filed with the city, the city shall hold a public hearing to determine whether the variance should be granted. Notice of variance hearings shall follow the procedures in use at the time for providing notice for rezoning matters. After the conclusion of the variance hearing, the city council may then vote to approve/disapprove installation of speed tables in the study at its sole discretion, following the procedure for amendments to ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 22-14, § 1, 7-1-14) 
Sec. 12-112. - Approved speed tables. 
(a)  None. 
(Ord. No. 22-14, § 1, 7-1-14) 
Secs. 12-113-12-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLES V-X. - RESERVED 

Secs. 12-136-12-1000. - Reserved.

Sec. 12-1005. - Parking prohibited. 
Parking is prohibited in the following locations: 
Ampacet Drive. 
Bartow Street, both sides from Main Street north to Jones Street. Additionally, the curbs in this area shall be painted yellow and signage shall be placed every one hundred fifty (150) feet to indicate "No Parking". Except parking shall be permitted on Bartow Street on Sunday, from one (1) hour prior to church and one (1) hour after church service and for funerals the police department shall post appropriate signage or cover existing signage to allow same. Penalties for violation shall be the same as for other parking violations. 
Bartow Street, west side, from Main Street to West Avenue. 
Busch Drive from its intersection with Old Grassdale Road to the dead end of Busch Drive. 
Cantrell Street. 
Canyon Parkway.

Jones Street, both sides from West Carter Street to North Bartow Street. The curbing shall be painted yellow and signs installed every one hundred fifty (150) feet to indicate no parking. 
Leake Street from Bartow Street to Etowah Drive on both sides.

Sec. 12-1006. - Two-hour parking. 
(a)  Parking is limited to two (2) hours except as designated herein at the following locations: 
    Church Street, from Railroad Street to Gilmer Street. 
    Erwin Street, from Church Street to Main Street, shall be two-hour parking. 
    Gilmer Street, from Main Street to Cherokee Avenue, shall be two-hour parking. 
    Main Street, from Gilmer Street to Bartow Street, shall be two-hour parking, except that all property marked and signed handicapped parking spaces shall be exempt from this time limit, and that the three (3) spaces in front of 141 and 139 West Main Street and the two (2) spaces located in front of 144 West Main Street shall be fifteen-minute parking. 
    Public Square, west side, from Church Street to Main Street, and Public Square, east side, from Cherokee Avenue to Main Street. 
    Wall Street, from Church Street to Main Street. 
(b)  No parking as allowed adjacent to any yellow-curbed area within the City of Cartersville city limits. Violators shall be subject to a fine of ten dollars ($10.00) per violation per thirty (30) minutes. 
(Code 1976, App. 1, § 111; Ord. No. 7-86, 4-9-86; Ord. No. 06-95, 3-16-95; Ord. No. 43-99, §§ 1-7, 10-7-99; Ord. No. 02-00, § 1, 1-3-00; Ord. No. 32-01, 8-16-01) 
Sec. 12-1007. - One-hour parking. 
    Parking is limited to one (1) hour in the following locations: 
    Erwin Street, from Cherokee Avenue to Church Street. 
(Code 1976, App. 1, § 112) 
Sec. 12-1008. - Thirty-minute parking. 
    Parking is limited to thirty (30) minutes at the following locations: 
    Erwin Street, east side, the first three (3) spaces and the seventh (7th) space north of Main Street. 
    Public square, west side, the four (4) spaces closest to Main Street. 
(Ord. No. 43-86, 1-2-87; Ord. No. 06-95, 3-16-95) 
Sec. 12-1009. - Fifteen-minute parking. 
    Parking is limited to fifteen (15) minutes at the following locations: 
    Church Street. The three (3) parking spaces on Church Street in front of Spring City Knitting and the first four (4) spaces east of the Cartersville High School entrance. 
(Ord. No. 5-87, § 1, 1-29-87) 
Sec. 12-1010. - Turn lanes. 
    Turn lanes shall be marked in the following locations: 
    Main Street, both sides at its intersection with Tennessee Street and at its intersection with Gilmer Street. 
(Code 1976, App. 1, § 110)

    Crosswalks shall be established at the following locations: 
    Across Church Street from U.S. Post Office to sidewalk adjacent to Cartersville High School. 
(Ord. No. 5-87, § 3, 1-29-87)

Sec. 12-1013. - Prohibited parking in evening hours. 
(a)  That parking shall be prohibited on the following street between the hours of 8:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m. any day, except as provided for in this section: 
(1)  No parking on both sides of Church Street from the intersection of Church Street and Tennessee Street to the intersection of Church Street and North Dixie Avenue. 
(b)  That parking shall be prohibited in the following areas when posted by twenty-four-hour notice, and any vehicles parked in the areas listed herein are subject to towing and all costs associated therewith and a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for violation of this section: 
(1)  The parking area bounded by Public Square on the West, Church Street on the North, CSX Railroad on the east, and Cherokee Avenue on the south; 
(2)  The parking lot on the southeast corner of Cherokee Avenue and Erwin Street; 
(c)  Additionally, in the parking areas defined in subsection (b) of this section, the city authorizes the downtown development authority and/or the city manager to close said parking areas for scheduled events downtown as authorized by the downtown development authority or mayor and city council. 
(1)  In the event a scheduled event requires the closing of the parking area, the city and/or downtown development authority shall post signs at the entrances and exits of the parking areas stating the date and time during which said parking area shall be closed, at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to the scheduled event. 
(2)  If any vehicle is parked in said parking areas in subsection (b) of this section during the prohibited time, said vehicles are subject to towing with all costs assessed to the vehicle's owner and a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(d)  The restrictions on parking provided for in subsections (b) and (c) of this section are not applicable to vehicles owned by the City of Cartersville. 
(Ord. No. 30-93, 9-16-93; Ord. No.40-00, 9-7-00) 
Sec. 12-1014. - Prohibited truck traffic. 
(a)  No vehicles over six (6) wheels on Martin Luther King, Jr. Drive, east of Galt Street. 
(b)  Latimer Road, no vehicles over six (6) wheels allowed and no dump trucks. 
(c)  No vehicles over six (6) wheels on Charles Street from Cassville Road to West Cherokee Street. 
(d)  No vehicles over six (6) wheels on Brookwood Drive. 
(e)  These prohibitions do not apply to moving vehicles on the actual day of a move from a residence or other establishment, authorized emergency vehicles, and authorized government vehicles. 
(f)  The city is authorized to post appropriate signage on said roads to notify the public of said restrictions. 
(g)  No trucks over six (6) wheels on Lee Street between West Avenue and Etowah Drive. 
(h)  No trucks over six (6) wheels to make right turns onto North Erwin Street from West Main Street, westbound (SR 113/61). 
(i)  No through trucks over six (6) wheels on West Avenue from its intersection with Etowah Drive to the intersection with South Erwin Street. 
(j)  No through trucks over six (6) wheels on Mockingbird Drive from its intersection with Tennessee Street/Georgia Highway 61 to the intersection with Joe Frank Harris Parkway/State Route 3/US Highway 41. 
(k)  No through trucks over six (6) wheels on Bartow Street from its intersection with West Main Street/State Route 61 to the intersection with West Avenue. 
(1)  No through trucks over six (6) wheels on Jones Mill Road from its intersection with Porter Street to the railroad overpass. 
(m)  No through trucks over six (6) wheels on Church Street from its intersection with Bartow Street to the intersection with Wofford Street. 
(Ord. No. 67-00, 1-4-01; Ord. No. 27-01, 8-16-01; Ord. No. 49-01, § 1, 12-20-01; Ord. No. 10-06, § 1, 3-2-06; Ord. No. 23-09, § 1, 5-7-09; Ord. No. 05-11, § 1, 1-20-11; Ord. No. 16-17, § 1, 6-1-17) 
Sec. 12-1015. - Parking prohibited. 
(a)  Parking on the street is prohibited between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., Monday through Friday from five hundred (500) feet in all directions from the intersection of Pine Grove Road an Douthit Ferry Road. 
(b)  Parking on Jones Street on the west side from St. Francis Street North to Aubrey Street is prohibited from 7:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. daily. 
(c)  No parking on Sunday between the hours of 12:00 a.m. to 11:59 p.m. on Douglas Street between Howard and Church Street. 
(d)  No parking, for four hundred eighty-five (485) feet on both sides of Fairview Street from the intersection of Fairview Circle westward on Fairview Street, said area is to be yellow curbed. 
(e)  No parking on both sides of Ampacet Drive, said area is to be marked with signage reflecting "No Parking Anytime." 
(f)  Noble Street on the east side from Cherokee Street for approximately one hundred forty (140) feet, said area shall be designated by yellow curbing. 
(Ord. No. 38-01, 9-6-01; Ord. No. 65-04, 9-2-04; Ord. No. 37-05, § 1, 7-7-05; Ord. No. 31-06, § 1, 6-1-06; Ord. No. 49-06, § 1, 7-20-06; Ord. No. 47-08, § 1, 11-6-08) 
Sec. 12-1016. - Engine brake prohibited. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to prohibit the excessive, loud, unusual or explosive use of engine and compressed air-braking devices within designated areas in the City of Cartersville. 
(b)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section the following words and phrases are defined as follows: 
(1)  Compression brake. Any device which, by the release of compressed air within an engine cylinder prior to the ignition of fuel therein, results in the slowing of said vehicle and/or braking without the use of wheel brakes and said devices are commonly referred to as "Jacob's Brakes," "Jake Brakes," "Dynamic Brake," "C-Brake," or "Paccar Brake." 
(2)  Engine brake. Any device which, by the release of compressed air within an engine cylinder prior to the ignition of fuel therein, results in the slowing of said vehicle and/or braking without the use of wheel brakes, said devises commonly referred to as "Jacob's Brakes," "Jake Brakes," "Dynamic Brake," "C-Brake," or "Paccar Brake." 
(c)  Prohibitions. It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to use or operate or cause to be used or operated within designated areas in the City of Cartersville, any engine brake, compression brake or mechanical exhaust device designed to aid in the braking or deceleration of any vehicle that results in excessive, loud, unusual or explosive noise from such vehicle, unless such use is necessary to avoid imminent danger. Such prohibition shall be applicable only to those public highways or portions specifically identified in this section. 
(d)  Areas of prohibition. The prohibition set forth herein shall apply to the following public highways in the City of Cartersville, Georgia or portions thereof: 
(1)  State Route 61 from its intersection with Attaway Drive to the intersection with West Main Street. 
(e)  Signage. Signs stating "VEHICLE NOISE LAWS ENFORCED" or "ENGINE BRAKE ORDINANCE ENFORCED" may be installed at locations deemed appropriate by the public works director to advise motorists of the prohibitions contained in this section, except that no sign stating "VEHICLE NOISE LAWS ENFORCED" or "ENGINE BRAKE ORDINANCE ENFORCED" shall be installed on a state highway without a permit from the Georgia Department of Transportation. The provisions of the ordinance codified in this section shall be in full force and effect even if no signs are installed. 
(f)  Exceptions. Emergency vehicles shall be exempt from the application of this section. 
(Ord. No. 17-17, § 1, 6-1-17) 
Secs. 12-1017-12-1040. - Reserved. 
Chapter 13 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Municipal court, § 6.01 et seq. 
State Law reference- Municipal court, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1 et seq. 

Sec. 13-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the words "court" and "judge" shall, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise, refer to the municipal court of the city and the judge of that court respectively. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 13-2. - Regular sessions. 
(a)  A regular session of the court shall be held once each week at a fixed hour of a fixed day as may be determined by the judge, provided such session may be dispensed with when there is no business pending in the court and no cases ready for trial. 
(b)  There shall be no regular session of court the weeks of Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's, or on any legal holiday unless otherwise determined by the judge. Additionally, in any month with five (5) Mondays, there shall be no regular session of court on the fifth Monday of the month unless determined by the judge. 
(c)  Bail or bond. In all cases in which bail or bond is posted, all required surcharges are to be added to same and shall be posted. 
(d)  All surcharges shall be paid into the city's general fund or dedicated accounts as may be established from time to time and are to be disbursed as provided for by law. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1001; Ord. No. 03-17, §§ 1, 2, 12-15-16) 
Sec. 13-3. - Special sessions. 
    The judge may hold special sessions when, in his judgment, it is necessary or there is urgent cause for the trial of accused persons. The necessity or urgency of the cause shall be presumed from the fact of such sessions' being held. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1002) 
Sec. 13-4. - Adjournments and continuances. 
    The judge may adjourn any regular or special session of court to another day or another hour in the same day, and may grant continuances of any case for trial before him. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1003) 
Sec. 13-5. - Formal opening. 
    No formal opening of the court shall be necessary or required, provided the regular sessions may not open prior to the arrival of the regular hour. All parties defendant shall have at least six (6) hours' notice of a special session at which such parties are to be tried. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1004) 
Sec. 13-6. - Attendance of police officers. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the chief of police or his deputy, or some member of the police force designated by the chief, to attend each session of the court. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of each policeman making the arrest or having knowledge of the case for or against the defendant, to attend the trial of any person brought before the court charged with violating any city ordinance. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1005) 
Sec. 13-7. - Clerk of court. 
    The judge shall be authorized to appoint any city employee to serve as clerk of the court. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1006) 
Sec. 13-8. - Compliance with subpoenas. 
    Any person not exempt by law, who resides within the city, who fails or refuses to appear when subpoenaed to do so as a witness in any trial before the recorder shall be subject to punishment by the judge as for a contempt committed in his presence. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1007) 
Sec. 13-9. - Docket. 
    The judge shall keep a docket for the docketing of all cases of persons charged with the commission of an offense against the ordinances of the city. The docket may be maintained and generated by computer. The judge shall docket each case in its regular order with such specifications of the charge as will impart notice of the nature of the charge. He shall enter his judgment in the case on the docket, which shall be signed by him, either collectively or separately at his discretion. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1008) 
Sec. 13-10. - Contempt by failure to appear. 
    Any person charged with violating any of the penal ordinances of the city, whether under arrest or not, or under bond or not, who, after being notified of the charge and notified in writing by any policeman of the city to appear before the court at any designated term or time for trial, and who fails or refuses to appear at the time stated in the notice, shall be guilty of a contempt of court, and may be punished by the judge as for contempt committed in his presence. Provided, no person subject to the provisions of this chapter shall be punished as for contempt who has posted cash bond and forfeited such cash bond unless resummoned to appear before the judge. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1009) 
Sec. 13-11. - Corporations-Service of process; trial. 
    Whenever a corporation shall violate any of the penal provisions of this Code or any ordinance of the city, a warrant shall be issued against such corporation for such violation. The clerk of the court shall issue a copy of the warrant to be served by any policeman of the city upon any officer of the corporation to be found in the city, or upon the agent, superintendent or person in charge of the business of the corporation in the city. The policeman serving such warrant shall, at the time of service, notify the person upon whom such service is made, in writing, of the time and place of trial and shall make an entry upon the warrant showing the time of service and upon whom made, and shall return the same to the court and docket the case. The case shall stand for trial in the order and manner as cases against individuals for the violation of ordinances of the city. 
    If upon the trial, the defendant corporation fails to appear, or appearing fails to plead, the judge of the municipal court shall cause to be entered a plea of not guilty, and trial shall proceed as though the defendant had appeared and pleaded, there shall be rendered judgment against it for the fine imposed by the judge of the municipal court, together with all costs of prosecution, upon which judgment the clerk of court shall issue an execution against the defendant, which shall be levied and collected by the chief of police as tax executions in favor of the city are levied and collected. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1010; Ord. No. 34-12, § 1, 8-2-12) 
Sec. 13-12. - Same-Failure to appear or plead. 
    If, upon trial, the defendant corporation fails to appear, or appearing, fails to plead, the court may cause to be entered a plea of not guilty, and trial may proceed as though the defendant had appeared and pleaded. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1011) 
Sec. 13-13. - Same-Judgment and execution. 
    Upon the conviction of any corporation, there shall be rendered judgment against it for the fine imposed by the judge, together with all costs of prosecution, upon which judgment the clerk of the court shall issue an execution against the defendant, which shall be levied and collected by the chief of police, as tax executions in favor of the city are now collected. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1012) 
Sec. 13-14. - Appearance bond-Procedure for accepting. 
    Offenses against the penal ordinances of the city shall be bailable as follows: 
(1)  The arresting officer or another officer designated by the chief of police, may accept bond of the accused, payable to the city, conditioned upon the appearance of the accused at the session of the court at which he has been ordered to appear to answer the charge against him. The date and time the accused is to appear shall be stated in the bond. 
(2)  Such bond shall be in writing in an amount the person taking the bond may deem proper, but not exceeding two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). Every bond shall be signed by the accused. 
(3)  The officer accepting the bond may accept as security a cash deposit in the amount of the bond; or in lieu thereof he may accept the signature as surety of another person at least eighteen (18) years of age whom he believes to be solvent and good for the amount of the bond. 
(4)  All bonds must be approved by the officer taking the bond, and shall be filed with the clerk of the court. 
(5)  At the time of posting bail or bond in any case involving a violation of a criminal or traffic law of this city or state, all surcharges shall be included in the amount of said bail or bond. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1013; Ord. No. 34-12, § 2, 8-2-12) 
Sec. 13-15. - Same-Forfeiture. 
    Any bonds taken pursuant to this chapter may be forfeited for nonappearance of the accused at the time and place for trial as stated in the bond by the following procedure: 
(1)  The judge shall call the case in its regular order, and, if the accused is not in court and does not answer the call, and, if no good and sufficient reason is given for his nonappearance, the judge shall enter on the docket of the court where the case is stated, "bond forfeited," or similar words showing that said bond is forfeited. 
(2)  Upon the forfeiture of any bond, the cash deposited as security shall be paid to the city clerk and shall become the property of the city. 
(3)  Upon the forfeiture of any bond signed by a person as surety, the clerk of the court shall issue an execution against the principal and surety on the bond for the amount thereof as tax executions are issued. Such execution shall be collected as tax executions are collected. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1014) 
Sec. 13-16. - Contempt of court. 
    The judge is hereby vested with the same power and authority to punish for contempt of court, and for the same acts, as is now vested in judges of superior courts of the state; provided, however, that punishment for contempt of court shall not exceed the penalties provided by section 6.03 of the charter. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1015) 
Sec. 13-17. - Fines, enforcement by levy and execution. 
    For fines that may be due by any defendant, execution may be issued by the city clerk and collected as tax executions are collected. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1016) 
Sec. 13-18. - Judgment and sentences. 
    Upon a judgment or plea of guilty the court shall impose sentence. The court may: 
(1)  Impose a fine, with or without a commitment for confinement, compulsory work or both; 
(2)  Commit the defendant to confinement, compulsory work or both; 
(3)  Suspend the execution of the sentence in whole or in part; 
(4)  Defer the execution of the sentence or any portion or portions thereof to one (1) or more fixed dates in the future; 
(5)  May revoke, alter, amend or charge a sentence at any time, provided the sentence is not increased; or 
(6)  Place on probation. 
(7)  The court may punish for violations within its jurisdiction a fine not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or imprisonment for six (6) months, or both, except as otherwise provided by this Code or state law. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1017; Ord. No. 34-12, § 7, 8-2-12) 
Sec. 13-19. - Use of city prisoners. 
    The judge, in his discretion, may require persons given jail sentences in the court to work out such sentences in any public service work or on the public streets under the supervision of the chief of police or someone designated by the chief of police. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1018) 
Sec. 13-20. - Speeding violations. 
(a)  In addition to the fines imposed by the city for speeding violation under Georgia law and city ordinances, an additional amount is to be imposed by the court as follows: 
1st offense: None 
2nd offense: $30.00 
3rd offense: $60.00 
4th offense: $100.00 
(b)  In the event that this additional amount causes the total fine to exceed the limits imposed by the State of Georgia, then the amount over said limit shall not be assessed. 
(Ord. No. 45-06, § 1, 7-6-06) 
Sec. 13-21. - Weapons not allowed in municipal courtroom and adjacent facilities. 
    Firearms or other weapons, including, without limitation, any knife, razor, razor blade, ice pick or similar device having a sharp point, bat, baton, stun or tazer gun, any device capable of discharging harmful projectiles, pepper spray, and all similar items, shall not be worn or brought into the courtrooms of the municipal court or into the buildings in which they are located, except with the specific authorization of the court or the chief of police. 
    The following persons or groups are exempted from this prohibition: 
(1)  Law enforcement officers employed by the State of Georgia; 
(2)  Local law enforcement officers employed by the City of Cartersville and Bartow County, including sheriff's deputies; 
(3)  District attorneys, assistant district attorneys, and the Attorney General of the State of Georgia; 
(4)  Law enforcement officers of the United States of America, including federal probation officers who are authorized by law or by federal court to wear or carry firearms; 
(5)  Any person appointed by the municipal court judge as a bailiff, provided such person is licensed to carry firearms or otherwise permitted to carry a firearm under state law; 
(6)  Any person otherwise authorized by law to carry firearms or weapons within a Superior Courtroom of the State of Georgia. 
    Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-6 of the City of Cartersville Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 34-12, § 3, 8-2-12) 
Sec. 13-22. - Conduct in municipal courtroom. 
(a)  No person shall, while present within the courtrooms of the municipal court or in the buildings in which they are located, engage in any conduct which may reasonably disturb or interfere with any session of the municipal court or interfere with the business of any municipal court employee, including, without limitation, engaging in actions which disturb or endanger the public peace or decency by any disorderly conduct, such as the use profane or obscene language, being noisy, boisterous, or engaging in any riotous conduct, engaging in, promoting, aiding, or abetting any fight, riot, or disorderly proceeding, acting in a violent or tumultuous manner, using opprobrious or abusive words of another person in such other person's presence which by their very utterance tend to incite to an immediate breach of the peace, or recklessly or knowingly committing any act which may reasonably be expected to interfere with or disrupt proceedings before municipal court or interfere with its employees. 
(b)  The municipal court judge shall have the authority to preserve and enforce order in his or her immediate presence and, as near thereto as is necessary, to prevent interruption, disturbance, or hindrance to municipal court proceedings. In addition to the penalties which may be imposed pursuant to subsection (d) below, any person who fails to comply with an order of the judge of municipal court as to such person's conduct while within the courtrooms of the municipal court or the buildings in which they are located shall be guilty of contempt and shall be subject to the appropriate disciplinary action. 
(c)  The municipal court judge shall have full power and authority to make reasonable rules and regulations necessary and proper to secure the peaceful, efficient and successful administration of the business of said court, including the power to delegate authority to law enforcement personnel to achieve such purpose. 
(d)  Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-6 of the City of Cartersville Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 34-12, § 4, 8-2-12) 
Sec. 13-23. - Processing fees; fines. 
(a)  The municipal court chief judge may recommend a schedule of fees to assist the court in its operation and budget. The council must approve any such schedule, but if the council does not act within thirty (30) days of the court's recommendation, the fee schedule will become effective. 
(b)  The council may set city fines for violations of city ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 34-12, § 5, 8-2-12) 
Sec. 13-24. - Surcharges and court costs. 
(a)  State surcharges. The municipal court shall impose all add-on fees or surcharges required by state, federal or local law. 
(b)  Interpreter fees. The municipal court shall be authorized to impose fees for providing an accused with the services of an interpreter in accordance with the rules and regulations set forth by the Georgia Supreme Court. 
(c)  Bail or bond. In all cases in which bail or bond is posted, all required surcharges are to be added to same and shall be posted. 
(d)  All surcharges shall be paid into the city's general fund or dedicated accounts as may be established from time to time and are to be disbursed as provided for by law. 
(e)  The judge, mayor, or city council may impose additional surcharges as authorized by the Charter or state law. 
(Ord. No. 34-12, § 6, 8-2-12; Ord. No. 02-17, § 1, 12-15-16) 
Chapter 14 - NUISANCES[1] 
Footnotes:
