ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Driveway access to public streets; adoption of state rules. 
    The Georgia Department of Transportation Regulations for Driveway and Encroachment Control, current edition, and all amendments and appendixes thereto, is hereby adopted by reference and shall apply to all streets within the city. 
(Code 1976, § 6-5019; Ord. No. 65-07, § 1, 11-15-07) 
Sec. 22-2. - Damaging sidewalks or curbs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to unload upon or to load from the paved sidewalks in the city any heavy goods of any description whatever, in such manner as to injure and damage said sidewalks or the curbs, or any part thereof, or in any other manner to cause damage to the sidewalks or curbs. 
(Code 1976, § 6-5006) 
Sec. 22-3. - Permit required for excavations. 
    No person shall make any opening in any street or sidewalk of the city without first obtaining a permit issued by the city manager. 
(Code 1976, § 6-5007) 
Sec. 22-4. - Drainage of water on sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to build or construct the roof of any building so that the water will flow or drop therefrom onto any street or sidewalk in the city. 
(Code 1976, § 6-5009) 
Sec. 22-5. - Display of merchandise on streets or sidewalks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to display merchandise of any sort on the public streets or sidewalks. 
(b)  Except as may be provided for by resolutions or ordinances of the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1976, § 9-1005; Ord. No. 13-95, 5-25-95) 
Sec. 22-6. - Spitting on sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to spit or expectorate on the sidewalks of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 6-5010) 
Sec. 22-7. - Sidewalk or right-of-way cafes. 
(1)  General conditions. 
a.  Purpose. The purpose of the regulations and standards in this chapter is to allow increased business and pedestrian traffic by providing safe and visually appealing opportunities for outdoor dining. 
b.  Outdoor dining in public right-of-way permitted. Outdoor dining is not permitted where the speed, volume or nearness of vehicular traffic is not compatible with sidewalk dining. All outdoor dining area must be adjacent to and incidental to the operation of an indoor restaurant or a building including an indoor restaurant. Use of the sidewalk must be confined to the actual sidewalk and public right-of-way frontage of the indoor restaurant building. Outdoor dining shall not be allowed within ten (10) feet of fire hydrant, fire department standpipe connection, fire escape, bus stop, any doorway posted as an exit loading zone, mailboxes or traffic signal stanchions. 
c.  Required sidewalk width. Outdoor dining is permitted on sidewalks only where the sidewalk is wide enough to adequately accommodate both the usual pedestrian traffic in the area and the operation of the proposed activity. The outdoor dining area shall leave not less than five (5) consecutive feet of sidewalk width at every point, which is clear and unimpeded for pedestrian traffic. 
d.  Alcoholic beverage restrictions. The service of alcoholic beverages shall be restricted solely to on-premise consumption by customers within the outdoor dining area. Each of the following standards apply to service of alcoholic beverages: 
(1)  The outdoor dining area must be immediately adjacent to and abutting to the indoor restaurant which provides it with food and beverage service; 
(2)  The outdoor dining area must be clearly separated from pedestrian traffic; 
(3)  The operator shall post a written notice to customers that the drinking or carrying of an open container of alcoholic beverage is prohibited and unlawful outside the outdoor dining area; 
(4)  The outdoor dining operating must maintain a valid alcoholic beverage license; 
(5)  All other requirements as provided for in the City of Cartersville Code of Ordinances. 
e.  Health standards. The operator shall not permit the following outside the building: tables preset with utensils, glasses, napkins, condiments, or busing service stations. Outdoor food preparation is not allowed except in compliance with conditions of an outdoor dining permit. All exterior surfaces within the outdoor dining area shall be easily cleanable and shall be kept clean at all times by the permittee. Restrooms sufficient for indoor and outdoor dining shall be provided in the adjoining indoor restaurant. The permittee shall be responsible for maintaining the outdoor dining area, including the sidewalk surface right-of-way and furniture and adjacent areas in a clean and safe condition. 
f.  Hours of operation. Outdoor cafes may only operate between 7:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight. 
g.  Special closures. Outdoor dining is a privilege. The city shall have the right and power, acting through the city manager, or his authorized agent, to prohibit the operation of an outdoor dining area at any time because of anticipated or actual problems and conflicts may arise from, but are not limited to, scheduled festivals and similar events or parades or marches, or repairs to the street right-of-way or sidewalk, or from demonstrations or emergencies occurring in the area. To the extent possible, the permittee shall be given prior written notice of any time period during which the operation of the outdoor dining area will be prohibited by the city. 
(2)  Qualifications; special report. The use of sidewalks and/or right-of-way for restaurant tables shall only be permitted incidental to the operation of a qualified licensed restaurant on private property as defined herein. For purposes of this chapter, a qualified licensed restaurant would be one which derives at least sixty (60) percent of its total annual gross food and beverage sales revenues from the sale of prepared meals or food. A request for the use of sidewalks and/or right-of-way shall be subject to compliance with this code, building code regulations, and all other legal requirements. 
(3)  Restrictions on use of sidewalks cafes. 
a.  In no event shall the uses permitted by this section reduce that portion of any sidewalk customarily used by pedestrians to less than five (5) feet in width. Any use permitted by this section shall not be closer than ten (10) feet to the street curbs at street intersection corners or closer than ten (10) feet to any street curb, or three (3) feet from any parking curb. 
b.  Tables and chairs must be placed more than five (5) feet from the front of the building in which the food is prepared, except as provided otherwise in subsection (i). 
c.  A minimum of at least one (1) suitable trash container must be furnished for every six (6) tables. 
d.  Tables and chairs and all other unsecured fixtures must be removed from the sidewalk at the close of business of the restaurant and shall be stored inside the restaurant during all non-operating hours. 
e.  The city reserves a right of access to all portions of the sidewalk included in areas permitted for the purposes of sidewalk repair or other necessary purposes. 
f.  Persons issued permits pursuant to this section shall maintain the sidewalk area in a clean and safe condition. 
g.  Only the area in front of a restaurant, as defined by that area in front of the restaurant building between the two (2) lines formed by projecting two (2) lines running along each side of the building perpendicular to the front of the building to a point at which each line intersects the roadway, may be used by the restaurant for the uses permitted by the division. Placement of tables and chairs will be permitted in an area more than ten (10) feet from the front of the building only when the code enforcement officer determines it is safe for use by the public and will not interfere with the use of the sidewalk by pedestrians. 
h.  Sidewalk cafes will only be permitted in the downtown business district as defined by the city zoning ordinance, and specifically limited to the following sidewalks, those fronting Wall Street, Church Street (under the bridge) and Public Square. 
i.  Only restaurants which are licensed for malt beverage and wine and/or distilled spirits pouring licenses may serve alcohol in a sidewalk cafe, and said area should be enclosed with a fence or other barrier enclosing tables and chairs which defines the serving area and restricts access thereto. The type and location of the fence or other barrier shall be as approved by the code enforcement officer. Additionally, for sidewalk cafe's serving alcohol the fenced in or barrier area must be next to and attached to the building and the sidewalk path is to be five (5) feet outside said location or fence. 
j.  Except as specifically provided in this chapter, the ownership, operating and maintenance of a sidewalk cafe shall be subject to all applicable laws, ordinances and regulations. 
k.  The code enforcement officer has the authority to modify, vary or impose additional conditions as may be required to make the cafe compatible with surrounding uses or as may be required to provide for sufficient useable traveling paths on the sidewalk. 
(4)  Restrictions on use of right-of-way cafes. 
a.  In no event shall the uses permitted by this subsection extend more than ten (10) feet from the building and must be at least three (3) feet from the edge of the actual street not including parking areas. 
b.  Tables and chairs cannot be placed more than ten (10) feet from the front of the building in which the food is prepared. 
c.  A minimum of at least one (1) suitable trash container must be furnished for every six (6) tables. 
d.  Tables and chairs and all other unsecured fixtures must be removed from the right-of-way at the close of business of the restaurant and shall be stored inside the restaurant during all nonoperating hours, unless said area can be secured and locked. 
e.  The city reserves a right of access to all portions of the right-of-way included in areas permitted for the purposes of maintenance, repair or other necessary purposes. 
f.  Persons issued permits pursuant to this section shall maintain the right-of-way area in a clean and safe condition. 
g.  Only the area in front of a restaurant, as defined by that area in front of the restaurant building between the two (2) lines formed by projecting two (2) lines running along each side of the building perpendicular to the front of the building to a point at which each line intersects the roadway, may be used by the restaurant for the uses permitted by the division. Placement of tables and chairs will be permitted in an area more than ten (10) feet from the front of the building only when the code enforcement officer determines it is safe for use by the public and will not interfere with the use of the right-of-way by pedestrians. 
h.  Tables and chairs must be separated from the remaining right-of-way by a permanent enclosure consisting of fences or other barriers. 
i.  Right-of-way cafes will only be permitted in the downtown business district as defined by the city zoning ordinance, but are limited to the east right-of-way on Museum Drive between Main Street and Leake Street. 
j.  Only restaurants which are licensed for malt beverage and wine and/or distilled spirits pouring licenses may serve alcohol in a right-of-way cafe, and said area should be enclosed with a fence or other barrier enclosing tables and chairs which defines the serving area, and the type and location of the fence or other barrier shall be as approved by the code enforcement officer. Additionally, for cafe's serving alcoholic beverages the fence or barrier must be next to and attached to the building. 
k.  Except as specifically provided in this chapter, the ownership, operating and maintenance of a right-of-way cafe shall be subject to all applicable laws, ordinances and regulations. 
(5)  Permit procedure. 
a.  An applicant for a permit under this section shall file said applications in the planning and development department to code enforcement officer on forms provided by that office. In addition to the application form, petitioner must submit a site plan of the proposed area and photos or specifications of the proposed furnishings and accessory signage. 
b.  The code enforcement officer shall verify the applicant is a qualified licensed restaurant operator in good standing at the specified location and shall collect all applicable fees as established by the city council and assure that the applicant for a permit under this chapter is in compliance with all other requirements of this chapter. Upon determination that the applicant satisfies all the requirements of this chapter, the code enforcement officer shall issue a permit authorizing the use of a sidewalk cafe or right-of-way cafe and shall provide any additional restrictions or conditions as may be necessary to assure compliance with this chapter. 
c.  Any applicant who shall be refused a permit by the code enforcement officer shall have ten (10) days from the date of such refusal to appeal to the mayor and city council, which shall then make a final decision as to whether the permit for a sidewalk or right-of-way cafe shall be issued. 
(6)  Insurance prerequisite. 
a.  No permit shall be issued pursuant to this section, unless the applicant shall furnish to the code enforcement officer evidence of public liability insurance, naming the city and the downtown development authority as insured parties and insuring them against any liability resulting from the uses permitted pursuant to this section. The coverage shall not be less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00). 
b.  No permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall be valid at any time the insurance required by this section is not maintained and evidence of its continuance filed with the planning and development department. 
(7)  Permit revocation. The permit may be revoked at any time if the applicant fails to comply with the provisions of all applicable laws, ordinances and regulations. Revocation may be made by written notice from the building inspector and served upon the applicant by certified mail or personal service. Upon receipt of such revocation notice, the applicant shall have ten (10) days to appeal such revocation to the city council, which shall make the final decision as to whether the permit shall be revoked. 
(8)  Fees. 
a.  An annual fee for each calendar year of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be due on the first regular day of business of the city following January 1 and shall be paid to the planning and development department building inspector. In addition to such annual fee, an additional fifty dollar ($50.00) application fee shall be paid by an applicant. 
b.  All fees required herein shall be in addition to any other fees or payments required elsewhere in this Code. 
(9)  Refunds and prorations. 
a.  When the permit fee has been paid during the first half of the calendar year, and the person paying such fee discontinues the business during the first half of the calendar year, the mayor and city manager may authorize the refunding of one-half (1/2) of such fee, provided all other fees and taxes owing by such person has been paid. 
b.  On any new sidewalk cafe permitted by the city after June 30 of each year and before October 1 of the same year, the permit fee shall be one-half (1/2) of the amount as set by ordinance. On any new sidewalk cafe permitted by the city after September 30 of each year, the amount of such permit fee shall be one-fourth (1/4) of the amount as set by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 11-95, 5-11-95; Ord. No. 66-00, 1-4-01; Ord. No. 20-03, § 1, 6-5-03; Ord. No. 51-08, § 1, 12-4-08) 
Sec. 22-8. - Temporary street closures. 
(1)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section, a "temporary street closure" shall mean a block party, local special event, festival, celebration, concert, or any similar occurrence to be conducted within an area not exceeding one (1) city block or one (1) intersection or the Friendship Plaza, in the City of Cartersville and which is sponsored solely by the owners, residents or tenants in the area, or their organization. Any temporary street closure authorized in whole or in part by the city for municipal purposes, including but not limited to, conveyance of traffic, travel, or facilitating of an event of a general civic or public nature, is exempt from this section. 
(2)  Permit required. No person, firm, corporation or organization shall participate in, advertise for or in any way promote, organize, control, manage, solicit, or induce participation in a temporary street closure unless a permit has fist been obtained from the director of planning and development or their designee. No person, firm, corporation or organization shall violate any of the terms of a permit issued for a temporary street closure or this section, nor join or participate in any permitted activity under this section over the objection of the permit holder, nor in any manner interfere with the progress or orderly conduct of a temporary street closure. 
(3)  Application for permit. An application for a permit for temporary street closure shall be made upon a form provided by the director of planning and development or their designee and shall contain all of the following information: 
(a)  The name, residence and business address, and phone number of each person and organization sponsoring the temporary street closure. If an organization, the application shall contain the names, residence and business addresses, and phone numbers of the president or chairman thereof, and all other persons: 
1.  Having an interest or position of management or control in such organization; 
2.  Who are or will be engaged in organizing, promoting, controlling, managing or soliciting participation in such temporary street closure; 
(b)  The date, or dates, and beginning and ending hours of such temporary street closure; 
(c)  The block or intersection in which such closure will occur; 
(d)  The estimated number of persons who will participate; 
(e)  The purpose of the temporary street closure; 
(f)  Whether parking is requested to be restricted or prohibited during such closure; 
(g)  Whether any sound amplification equipment is proposed to be used, and if so, information describing such sound amplification. No sound amplification equipment shall be used in any way which would constitute nuisance to adjoining property owners or contrary to section 11-101 of the City of Cartersville Code of Ordinances; 
(h)  Whether or not charity, gratuity, or offerings will be solicited or accepted, or sales of food, beverages, alcohol or other merchandise will occur; 
(i)  Whether such temporary street closure will occupy all or only a portion of the street or intersection involved; and 
(j)  Such other information as the director of planning and development deems reasonably necessary in order to carry out his duties under this section. 
(4)  Time of filing. The application shall be filed not less than ten (10) days prior to the scheduled date of such temporary street closure. Failure to file on time is denial of a permit. 
(5)  Special activities. When an application is submitted for a permit to conduct an activity which, due to its proposed size or nature, cannot reasonably be conducted or maintained within a single location, the applicant shall designate proposed locations on a map submitted as part of the application, indicating distances from curbs, crosswalks, driveways, building entrances, and fire hydrants, which proposed locations shall be subject to the approval of the director of planning and development or their designee. All such encroachments shall meet all the following minimum location requirements: 
(a)  There shall at all times remain open for the passage of pedestrians a space of not less than five (5) feet in width. 
(b)  Equipment and displays associated with approved activities shall not be permitted at any of the following: 
1.  Within three (3) feet of the curb when adjacent to a traffic lane; 
2.  Within two (2) feet of any curb; 
3.  Within five (5) feet of the outer edge of any crosswalk or driveway measured in each direction parallel to the building line, and thence at a ninety-degree angle to the curb; and 
4.  Within five (5) feet of the outer edge of any entrance to any building, including doors and emergency exits, measured in each direction parallel to the building line or patio or deck line, and thence at a ninety-degree angel to the curb. 
(6)  Permit fee. All applications for a permit shall be accompanied by a processing fee of fifty dollars ($50.00), no part of which shall be refundable, provided however, that no such fee shall be assessed for a permit involving an activity sponsored by and conducted by a charitable organization or residential neighborhood. 
(7)  Nontransferability. No permit issued pursuant to this section shall be transferable except with the written approval of the director of planning and development or their designee. A written application for such a transfer shall be made to the director of planning and development or their designee and shall be accompanied by a filing and processing fee of ten dollars ($10.00) no part of which shall be refundable. The application for such transfer shall contain the same information as required herein for an initial application for a permit as set forth in ordinance. In the event of denial of such transfer, notification of and reasons for denial shall be set forth in writing and shall be sent to the applicant by mail or delivered in person. 
(8)  Barricades; litter collection. Applicants shall provide and remove such barricades and warning devised as are deemed necessary by and are acceptable to the director of planning and development or their designee. Applicants shall also provide for the collection and removal of all trash, garbage, and litter caused by or arising out of such temporary street closure. Each applicant shall enter into a written agreement, specifying the duties to be performed under this section. Such written agreement shall be in a form approved by the city attorney. 
(9)  Hold harmless. Applicants shall agree in writing to assume the defense of and indemnify and save harmless the city, its mayor, council members, boards, commissions, officers, employees and agents, from all suits, actions, damages or claims to which to city may be subjected of any kind or nature whatsoever resulting from, caused by, arising out of or as a consequence of such temporary street closure and the activities permitted in connection therewith. 
(10)  Personnel costs. Applicants shall pay to the city the costs of city personnel who are required by the city to work overtime hours or other than regular shift or perform duties during or as a result of such temporary street closure. Applicants shall deposit with the city a sum in an amount estimated by the director of planning and development or their designee. 
(11)  Compliance with laws. Prior to issuance of a permit under this section, all applicable ordinances and laws shall be complied with and all required permits and licenses shall be secured in connection with such temporary street closure, or the proposed activities associated therewith including, but not limited to, charitable solicitations, collections or acceptance of gratuities, the sale of food, beverages, alcohol, or other merchandise, or the use of candles, torches, fires, or other combustibles. 
(12)  Conditions in permits. Any permit granted under this section may contain conditions reasonably calculated to reduce or minimize the dangers and hazards to vehicular or pedestrian traffic and the public health, safety, tranquility, morals or welfare, including but not limited to, changes in time, duration, number of participants, or noise levels. 
(13)  Standards for issuance. A permit shall be issued by the director of planning and development or their designee, when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that all of the following circumstances exist: 
(a)  The applicant has not knowingly and with intent to deceive, made any false, misleading or fraudulent statements of material fact in the application for a permit or in any other document required pursuant to this ordinance; 
(b)  The applicant has met the standards in this section, and paid in advance any fee required and agrees to such conditions as are imposed in the permit; 
(c)  The time, duration, and size of the temporary street closure will not substantially disrupt the orderly and safe movement of other traffic; 
(d)  The temporary street closure is a size or nature such that it will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city as to prevent normal police protection to the city; 
(e)  The concentration of persons will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to areas contiguous to such street closure; 
(f)  The temporary street closure will not unduly interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment on the way to a fire; 
(g)  The temporary street closures will not unduly interfere with the orderly operating of parks, hospitals, churches, schools or other public and quasi-public institutions in the city; 
(h)  The applicant has provided reasonable means for informing all persons listed in subsection (3), paragraph (a) of this section, and all other persons participating in the temporary street closure of the terms and conditions of such permit and the applicable laws; 
(i)  The permit must be approved by the following: Chief of police, fire chief, and director of planning and development. 
(14)  Notice of issuance or denial. Written notice of the issuance or denial of a permit shall be provided to the applicant within five (5) days of receipt of an application, or as soon as practicable if received less than ten (10) days in advance of the proposed date of the temporary street closure. If a permit is denied, said written notice shall state the reasons for denials. 
(15)  Appeals procedure. Upon the denial of a permit by the director of planning and development or their designee, the applicant may appeal by filing the application within seventy-two (72) hours or two (2) city working days, whichever is longer, with the city manager or his designated representative, who shall set the appeal for hearing within forty-eight (48) hours. The city manager will notify the applicant orally and in writing of the date and time of the hearing, provided that oral notification is not required if the applicant is not available either by telephone or in person at the city hall. After holding a hearing, the city manager may reverse, affirm or modify in any respect the determination of the director of planning and development or their designee. 
(16)  Waiver of time limitations. For good cause shown, the director of planning and development or their designee may waive the time limitation in subsection (4) for filing an application and the city manager may waive the time limitation in this subsection (16) for filing an appeal. 
(17)  Revocation of permit. Any permit for temporary street closure issued pursuant to this section may be revoked by the director of planning and development or their designee at any time when by reason of emergency, disaster, calamity, disorder, riot, extreme traffic conditions, violation of this section or of any permit conditions, or undue burden on public services, he determines that the health, safety, tranquility, morals or welfare of the public or the safety of any property requires such revocation. Notice of revocation of a permit shall be delivered in writing to at least one (1) person named upon the permit by personal service or by certified mail, or if the closure has commenced, orally, or in writing, by personal contract or service, or by telephone. Continuance of a temporary street closure after such notice has been delivered is unlawful. 
(Ord. No. 20-03, § 5, 6-5-03; Ord. No. 51-08, § 1, 12-4-08) 
Secs. 22-9-22-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARADES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Parade, as used in this article, means any parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant or procession of any kind, or any similar display, which will be conducted in or upon any street, right-of-way, or any park or other place owned or maintained by the city in which four (4) or more persons will participate. 
    Parade permit means a permit as required by this article. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6003; Ord. No. 7-94, 3-17-94) 
Secs. 22-27-22-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 22-36. - Required; exceptions. 
(a)  An application and permit shall be required for each such parade, provided however, only one (1) application and permit shall be required for each proposed parade. All such parades shall be conducted under the supervision of the person or persons making application for the same, and shall be conducted in a peaceable and orderly manner in compliance with the laws and ordinances applicable thereto. 
(b)  A parade permit shall be obtained from the city manager. The requirement for a parade permit is not applicable to: 
(1)  Funeral processions; 
(2)  Students going to and from school classes; and 
(3)  A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions; or 
(4)  Handbilling whether engaged in by an individual or group. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6003; Ord. No. 7-94, 3-17-94) 
Sec. 22-37. - Application. 
(a)  Filing generally. A person seeking issuance of a parade permit shall file an application with the city manager or his designee on forms provided by such officer. 
(b)  Filing period. An application for a parade permit shall be filed with the city manager or his designee not less than ten (10) days or more than one (1) year before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade. 
(c)  Late applications. The city manager or his designee, where good cause is shown therefor, shall have the authority to consider any application under this division which is filed less than four (4) business days before the date such parade is proposed to be conducted. 
(d)  Contents. The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade. 
(2)  If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, by or on behalf of an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of such organization. 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade chairperson and who will be responsible for its conduct. 
(4)  The date when the parade is to be conducted. 
(5)  The route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point. 
(6)  The approximate number of persons, animals and vehicles to constitute such parade, the type of animals and a description of the vehicles. 
(7)  The hours when such parade is to start and terminate. 
(8)  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets or right-of-way proposed to be traversed. 
(9)  The location by streets of any assembly areas for the parade. 
(10)  The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any such assembly area. 
(11)  If the parade is designed to be held by or on behalf of any person other than the applicant, a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade, authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf. 
(13)  Any additional information that the city manager or his designee shall find reasonably necessary for a fair determination as to whether the proposed parade will endanger public health, safety or welfare. 
(e)  [Review.] Applications shall be forwarded to the police chief for review and approval. The police chief, or designee, shall review the applications(s) for safety concerns, prior to the issuance of a permit. The police chief may deny the application's permit request for any public safety concerns. In the event of a denial, the applicant may revise the application to satisfy the concerns. Any such concerns or permit objections by the police chief shall be addressed in writing to the city manager's office within forty-eight (48) hours of receiving the application. The police chief may make recommendations regarding the parade route, or types and styles of floats, conveyances, etc. operated in the parade, should safety concerns arise. Parade permit applicants may appeal a denial or modification to the city manager as outlined in section 22-39, appeal from denial. The city manager may over-ride any such objections. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6003; Ord. No. 7-94, 3-17-94; Ord. No. 66-05, §§ 1, 2, 8-4-05; Ord. No. 06-11, § 1, 2-17-11) 
Sec. 22-38. - Issuance. 
    [The city manager or his designee shall issue a permit as provided in this section from a consideration of the application and from such information as may otherwise be obtained, unless he finds that:] 
(1)  The conduct of the parade will substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route; 
(2)  The conduct of the parade will interfere with the movement of fire fighting equipment en route to a fire. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6003; Ord. No. 7-94, 3-17-94; Ord. No. 29-96, § 1, 7-18-96) 
Sec. 22-39. - Appeal from denial. 
(a)  Any person aggrieved by the denial or restriction of a parade permit shall have the right to appeal the denial or restriction to the city council. The city council shall act upon the appeal at its next regular meeting or at an earlier special meeting called for the consideration of such appeals, but in any event, at least twenty-four (24) hours before the proposed starting time of the parade. 
(b)  The city council shall grant an applicant's appeal of restriction or denial of a permit as provided in this section from a consideration of the application and from such information as may otherwise be obtained, unless it finds that one (1) or more of the factors enumerated in section 22-38 is present. In considering the factors for denying an applicant's appeal of denial or restriction of a permit, the only considerations shall be those of public health, safety and welfare. No distinction may be made on the basis of the content of the message, the identification of the participants, or any other matter which does not directly and substantially impact on the imminent public health, safety and welfare. 
(c)  At least twenty-four (24) hours before the proposed starting time of the parade, the city council will provide the appellant with a written decision on the appeal, stating whether any denial or restriction is being upheld, and if so, the factual basis and reason for upholding each such denial or restriction. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6003; Ord. No. 7-94, 3-17-94) 
Sec. 22-40. - Contents. 
    Each parade permit shall state the following information: 
(1)  Starting time. 
(2)  Type of activity. 
(3)  Applicant's name. 
(4)  Date. 
(5)  Signature of city manager. 
(6)  Approximate duration of parade. 
(7)  Restrictions or conditions on parade allowed by subsection 22-39(b) and reasons therefor. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6003; Ord. No. 7-94, 3-17-94) 
Sec. 22-41. - Alternate permit. 
    The city manager or his designee, in denying an application for a parade permit, shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of the parade on a date, at a time, or over a route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within three (3) days after notice of acceptance with the city manager or his designee. An alternate parade permit shall conform to the requirements of, and shall have the effect of a parade permit under this article. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6003; Ord. No. 7-94, 3-17-94) 
Sec. 22-42. - Officials to be sent copies. 
    Immediately upon the issuance of a parade permit, the city manager or his designee shall send a copy thereof to the following: 
(1)  The mayor 
(2)  The fire chief 
(3)  The chief of police 
(4)  The city attorney 
(Code 1976, § 7-6003; Ord. No. 7-94, 3-17-94; Ord. No. 42-95, § 5, 10-12-95; Ord. No. 47-95, § 4, 11-9-95) 
Sec. 22-43. - Duties of permittee; permit to be carried. 
(a)  A permittee shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. 
(b)  The parade chairperson or other person heading or leading such activity shall carry the parade permit upon his person during the conduct of the parade. 
(c)  The chairperson or other person heading or leading such activity shall remain at the point of termination of all such permitted events until the last participant arrives at the point of termination. 
(d)  The permittee shall notify each participant or group that the scattering, broadcasting, projecting, throwing of objects, edible items, printed materials or any other items, by parade participants, by hand or any other means, is prohibited. Participants may personally hand items to others along the parade route. The permittee may be denied any future permit, for any such violations, provided that the permittee has been warned of such penalties. 
(e)  The permittee shall be required to sign a statement stating that the permittee is aware of all the conditions and penalties for non-compliance, upon making application for a parade permit. A copy of the permit application, required changes; if any, and the statement of compliance shall be maintained by the city manager or his designee. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6003; Ord. No. 7-94, 3-17-94; Ord. No. 66-05, § 3, 8-4-05) 
Sec. 22-44. - Revocation. 
    The city manager or his designee shall have the authority to revoke a parade permit issued under this article where a permittee has failed to comply with reasonable permit directions and restrictions, and where the actions of a permittee pose an immediate threat to the safety of parade participants or the public. 
(Code 1976, § 7-6003; Ord. No. 7-94, 3-17-94) 
Sec. 22-45. - Penalties. 
    A willful, knowing violation of the permit requirement in section 22-36(a) of this article, after notice, may be subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), which may be enforced by the contempt powers of the municipal court of the city. No fine shall be assessed against any person who has not first received notice of this section, including the "late application provision." 
(Ord. No. 7-94, 3-17-94) 
Secs. 22-46-22-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Property taxes, § 10-21 et seq. 

Sec. 22-61. - Apportionment; due date. 
    In all cases where the streets, sidewalks, squares, public lanes or alleys of the city are graded, paved, macadamized or otherwise improved or the travel therein improved, the costs of the improvements shall be assessed as follows: 
(1)  One-third ( 1/3 ) of the cost shall be assessed against the real estate abutting on one (1) side of the street, and one-third ( 1/3 ) of the cost shall be assessed against the real estate abutting on the other side of the street. 
(2)  Curbs and gutters, sidewalks and storm drains installed along city streets at the request of the owner of the abutting property shall be paid for as follows: residential property, two-thirds ( 2/3 ) by owner and one-third ( 1/3 ) by city; commercial and industrial property; entire cost by owner. 
(3)  The aforementioned assessments shall be due thirty (30) days after billing. 
(Code 1976, § 6-5014) 
Sec. 22-62. - Priority of liens. 
    In all cases where two (2) or more streets, sidewalks, alleys, avenues or lanes, upon both or all of which one (1) or more tracts of land adjoins or abuts, are paved or improved, the liens of the several assessments, unless otherwise provided by law, shall rank in the order of the date or dates of the final resolution providing for the paving or improvement, the older shall be prior. 
(Code 1976, § 6-5016) 
Sec. 22-63. - Effect of erroneous assessment against exempt property. 
    If any assessment is made for an improvement against any real estate of any owner not legally subject to such assessment, the fact that such erroneous assessment is made shall not affect the validity of the assessment made against the real estate of any other owner or owners, but as to such legally exempt real estate, the city shall be treated as the owner for the purposes of the assessment and shall pay for the improvements of such area. 
(Code 1976, § 6-5015) 
Sec. 22-64. - Effect of error in description of property or designation of owner; manner of designation in bonds. 
(a)  In cases where any street, sidewalk, alley, avenue or lane is paved or improved, errors or inaccuracies of description of any property against which the appropriate charge or assessment is made or inaccurate or erroneous designation of the owner or owners, or other irregularities shall not affect the validity of the charge or assessment or of any bonds issued thereon. 
(b)  Where any of such adjoining or abutting properties is held by more than one (1) person in common ownership or in varying or different quantities, it shall be a sufficient designation of the owners in any bond issued on the assessment to name one (1) of the common or various owners, followed by the words "et al" and by designating the tract so owned by the number by which it is designated in the assessment. 
(Code 1976, § 6-5017) 
Secs. 22-65-22-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DESIGN STANDARDS FOR PUBLIC WORKS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-76. - Scope. 
(a)  This article governs the construction of residential, commercial, mobile homes, apartments, condominiums and semipublic places, with regard to earth moving, storm drainage, paving and installation of utilities. 
(b)  The following utility installations shall conform to the requirements of this article: 
(1)  Telephone. 
(2)  Cable TV. 
(3)  Electrical lines, if not installed by the city. 
(4)  Natural gas lines, if not installed by the city. 
(Code 1976, § 8-5001(a); Ord. No. 18-79, § 1.2.5, 7-19-79) 
Sec. 22-77. - Violations. 
    Any work not meeting the requirements of this article shall be corrected by the contractor. Should the work not be corrected within sixty (60) days after notification by the city inspector, a stop work order shall be issued by the public works department. Further failure by the contractor and developer shall be an offense. 
(Ord. No. 18-79, § 1.3.4, 7-19-79) 
Sec. 22-78. - Compliance with state standards. 
    Unless otherwise specifically set forth by this article, all of the materials, methods of construction, and workmanship for the work covered in reference to street construction and storm drainage construction shall conform to the latest standard specifications of the state department of transportation. 
(Code 1976, § 8-5001(b)) 
Sec. 22-79. - Plans, permits, etc. 
(a)  All phases of construction shall require construction plans. A construction permit must be obtained, at no cost, from the construction inspector at the public works department after the construction plans are approved. 
(b)  Grading plans are required prior to clearing and grubbing and prior to the beginning of any earth moving. 
(c)  Storm drainage plans are required if required grading work does not include installation of storm drainage pipe and other drainage construction with grading plans. 
(d)  Water and sewer line construction plans are required if such lines will not be installed by the city. 
(e)  Curbing plans are required after water and sewer lines have been installed and prior to the installation of any curb and gutter. 
(f)  A base and paving plan is required after the curb and gutter has been completed and prior to setting and priming the base. 
(Ord. No. 18-79, §§ 1.2, 1.2.1-1.2.4, 1.2.7, 7-19-79) 
Sec. 22-80. - Inspections. 
(a)  Authorized representatives of the city shall have access to the work for inspection at any time. When an inspection for approval of the work is needed, the developer or his representative shall notify the chief inspector twenty-four (24) hours prior to the desired day of inspection. 
(b)  A final field inspection of all improvements shall be held before conditional acceptance of the work and before the start of the one-year warranty period. 
(c)  When construction has been completed, the developer or his representative shall meet with an authorized representative from the public works department at the job site. 
(d)  Permits shall be examined at this time to ensure that the work has been accepted, and the construction plans shall be checked against what has been constructed to ensure that the work is completed. 
(e)  When all phases of work have been completed, a letter of acceptance will be issued by the public works department within thirty (30) days of final approval. 
(f)  A final field inspection of all installations shall be held by the city after each installation and prior to installation of the base and paving. 
(Ord. No. 18-79, §§ 1.1, 1.2.6, 1.3, 1.3.1-1.3.3, 7-19-79) 
Sec. 22-81. - Foreign material on streets. 
    The developer and builders shall be responsible for keeping dirt, mud, building materials, concrete, etc., off the pavement and curbing during construction of buildings in all developments covered by this article. Before the streets are accepted by the city all litter and trash shall be removed from the dedicated rights-of-way and surrounding areas. 
(Ord. No. 18-79, § 2.12, 7-19-79) 
Sec. 22-82. - Sign retroreflectivity procedure. 
    The 2009 Manual on Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) - Section 2A.08 latest edition, as may be amended or republished is adopted and is to be enforced in regard to the visual "Nightime Inspection Method and the Consistent Parameters Procedure" as the city's technique for maintaining sign retroreflectivity levels. The guidelines for inspection are the current page 20 and page 22 of the FHWA "Sign Retroreflectivity Guidebook" for small agencies, dated September 2009, as may be amended or republished. The Public Works Department of the City of Cartersville is responsible for carrying out this method and procedure. 
(Ord. No. 02-13, § 1, 2-21-13) 
Secs. 22-83-22-90. - Reserved.

Footnotes:

ARTICLE V. - SOLICITATION PERMITS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-106. - No solicitation on streets or highways. 
    Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-97(b) the city prohibits any person from standing or entering on a highway and public streets for the purpose of soliciting employment, business solicitations, and/or contributions from the occupant of any vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 48-01, 11-15-01) 
Sec. 22-107. - Definitions. 
    Event is any charitable solicitation within the city. 
(Ord. No. 48-01, 11-15-01) 
Sec. 22-108. - Exceptions. 
    Pursuant to the authority conferred unto the city by O.C.G.A. § 40-6-97.1, the city adopts the following procedures and permitting requirements for charitable organizations soliciting on highways and public streets as stated in this article. 
(Ord. No. 48-01, 11-15-01) 
Sec. 22-109. - Hearing officer. 
    The city council appoints the municipal court judge as the hearing officer for all appeals pursuant to section 22-121 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 48-01, 11-15-01) 
Secs. 22-110-22-115. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CHARITABLE ORGANIZATIONS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 48-01, adopted November 15, 2001, enacted a new Div. 2, §§ 22-115-22-140. At the discretion of the editor said sections have been renumbered as §§ 22-116-22-140 as set out herein, to better fit the format of the Code. 

Sec. 22-116. - Definitions 
    Charitable organizations for the purpose of this article mean organizations which have a 501(c) certificate from the Internal Revenue Service, nonprofit corporations, churches and public and private schools. 
(Ord. No. 48-01, 11-15-01) 
Sec. 22-117. - Generally. 
    No charitable organization is allowed to solicit funds on any public street or highway without first obtaining a permit. 
(Ord. No. 48-01, 11-15-01) 
Sec. 22-118. - Permit requirements. 
(a)  All requests for permits must be submitted to the city at least five (5) business days before the requested activity; 
(b)  All applications for permits must include at a minimum the following information: 
(1)  Name of organization; 
(2)  Type of organization; 
a.  501 corporation (C) include certificate of existence; 
b.  Church; 
c.  Public or private school; 
d.  Nonprofit corporation under the laws of the State of Georgia, to include a certificate of existence. 
(3)  Name of organizer; 
(4)  Address; 
(5)  Proposed activity, purpose, area of activity; 
(6)  Adult supervisor, name; 
(7)  Date and times of activity; 
(8)  Participants and ages. 
(Ord. No. 48-01, 11-15-01) 
Sec. 22-119. - Required; exceptions. 
(a)  An application and permit shall be required for each such event, provided however, only one (1) application and permit shall be required for each proposed event. All such events shall be conducted under the supervision of the person or persons making application for the same, and shall be conducted in a peaceable and orderly manner in compliance with the laws and ordinances applicable thereto. 
(b)  An event permit shall be obtained from the city manager. The requirement for an event permit is not applicable to: 
(1)  A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
(Ord. No. 48-01, 11-15-01) 
Sec. 22-120. - Application. 
(a)  Filing generally. A person seeking issuance of an event permit shall file an application with the city manager or his designee on forms provided by such officer. 
(b)  Filing period. An application for an event permit shall be filed with the city manager or his designee not less than five (5) business days nor more than sixty (60) calendar days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the event. 
(c)  Late applications. The city manager or his designee, where good cause is shown therefor, shall have the authority to consider any application under this division which is filed less than five (5) business days before the date such event is proposed to be conducted. 
(d)  Contents. The application for an event permit shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such event; 
(2)  If the event is proposed to be conducted for, by or on behalf of an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and the authorized and responsible heads of such organization; 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the event chairperson and who will be responsible for its conduct; 
(4)  The date when the event is to be conducted; 
(5)  The location of the event; 
(6)  The approximate number of persons and their ages, to constitute such event; 
(7)  The hours when such event is to start and terminate; 
(8)  The location by streets of any assembly areas for the event; 
(9)  The time at which units of the event will begin to assemble at any such assembly area; 
(10)  If the event is designed to be held by or on behalf of any person other than the applicant, a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the event, authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf; 
(11)  Any additional information that the city manager or his designee shall find reasonably necessary for a fair determination as to whether the proposed event will endanger public health, safety or welfare. 
(Ord. No. 48-01, 11-15-01) 
Sec. 22-121. - Issuance. 
    The city manager or his designee shall issue a permit as provided in this article from a consideration of the application and from such information as may otherwise be obtained, unless he finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of the event will substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route; 
(2)  The conduct of the event will interfere with the movement of fire fighting equipment en route to a fire, or other emergency services; 
(3)  The conduct of the event is contrary to the public's health, safety and general welfare. 
(Ord. No. 48-01, 11-15-01) 
Sec. 22-122. - Appeal from denial. 
(a)  Any person aggrieved by the denial or restriction of an event permit shall have the right to appeal the denial or restriction to the hearing officer. The hearing officer shall act upon the appeal at a hearing to be scheduled for the consideration of such appeals, but in any event, at least forty-eight (48) hours before the proposed starting time of the event. 
(b)  The hearing officer shall grant an applicant's appeal of restriction or denial of a permit as provided in this section from a consideration of the application and from such information as may otherwise be obtained, unless it finds that one (1) or more of the factors enumerated in section 22-119 is present. In considering the factors for denying an applicant's appeal of denial or restriction of a permit, the only considerations shall be those of public health, safety and welfare. No distinction may be made on the basis of the content of the message, the identification of the participants, or any other matter which does not directly and substantially impact on the imminent public health, safety and welfare. 
(c)  At least forty-eight (48) hours before the proposed starting time of the event, the hearing officer will provide the appellant with a written decision on the appeal, stating whether any denial or restriction is being upheld, and if so, the factual basis and reason for upholding each such denial or restriction. 
(d)  The hearing officer shall have the authority to conduct said hearing, tender a final decision, and the appellant and appellee will have all rights accorded to individuals as if such hearing was conducted by the municipal court of the city and the rule of evidence and procedures thereof. 
(Ord. No. 48-01, 11-15-01) 
Sec. 22-123. - Contents. 
    Each event permit shall state the follows information: 
(1)  Starting time; 
(2)  Type of activity; 
(3)  Applicant's name; 
(4)  Date; 
(5)  Signature of city manager; 
(6)  Approximate duration of event; 
(7)  Restrictions or conditions on event allowed by subsection 22-120(b) and reasons therefor. 
(Ord. No. 48-01, 11-15-01) 
Sec. 22-124. - Alternate permit. 
    The city manager or his designee, in denying an application for an event, shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of the event on a date, at a time, or a location different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within three (3) days after notice of acceptance with the city manager or his designee. An alternate permit shall conform to the requirements of, and shall have the effect of a permit under this article. 
(Ord. No. 48-01, 11-15-01) 
Sec. 22-125. - Official to be sent copies. 
    Immediately upon the issuance of a event permit, the city manager or his designee shall send a copy thereof to the following; 
(1)  The mayor; 
(2)  The fire chief; 
(3)  The chief of police; 
(4)  The city attorney. 
(Ord. No. 48-01, 11-15-01) 
Sec. 22-126. - Duties of permittee; permit to be carried. 
(a)  A permittee shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances; 
(b)  The event chairperson or other person heading or leading such activity shall carry the event permit upon his person during the conduct of the event. 
(Ord. No. 48-01, 11-15-01) 
Sec. 22-127. - Revocation. 
    The city manager or his designee shall have the authority to revoke a event permit issued under this article where a permittee has failed to comply with reasonable permit directions and restrictions, and where the actions of a permittee pose an immediate threat to the safety of participants or the public. 
(Ord. No. 48-01, 11-15-01) 
Sec. 22-128. - Issuance requirements. 
    The city shall not issue any permit which does not fully comply with the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 48-01, 11-15-01) 
Sec. 22-129. - Prohibited times and street and highways. 
(a)  No solicitation is allowed during the following times: 
(1)  Between the hours of 11:30 a.m. and 1:30 p.m., Monday through Friday; 
(2)  After 4:00 p.m. Monday through Friday; 
(3)  Between the hours of 12:00 a.m. through 8:00 a.m. and after 6:00 p.m. on Saturday; 
(4)  Between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 1:30 p.m. and after 5:00 p.m. on Sunday. 
(b)  Prohibited streets: 
(1)  U.S. Highway 41 and all intersections thereof; 
(2)  The Main Street connector east of U.S. Highway 41; 
(3)  All bridges; 
(4)  Any and all streets or highways which have more than three (3) lanes of travel, including turn lanes. 
(Ord. No. 48-01, 11-15-01) 
Sec. 22-130. - Persons under eighteen. 
    All organizations who are permitted to solicit funds must have one (1) adult supervisor over the age of twenty-one (21) for every four (4) persons under the age of eighteen (18). 
(Ord. No. 48-01, 11-15-01) 
Sec. 22-131. - Fines and rules. 
(a)  Any person, organization, business or entity violating the provisions of this article is subject to a fine of up to one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day per violation per individual participant. 
(b)  Any person, organization, business or entity found guilty of violating this article may not be issued a permit for a two-year period from the date of the violation. 
(Ord. No. 48-01, 11-15-01) 
Secs. 22-131-22-140. - Reserved.
